Dear Stephanie Sears:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Eligibility requirements
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12504
Section • (3) An independent living home, staffed and operated by
Description the child placing agency, must be clean, safe, and
appropriate to the needs of the youth it serves.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
1

Allegation Once youth go into their rooms at their placement, they are
confined to their rooms. The youth cannot exit once their doors
are closed. There are no fire extinguishers in their rooms. The
windows do not open. There are limited staff.
Investigation Independent Living Supervisor (IL Supervisor) & Director of
Foster Care Services (Director of FC Services) were
interviewed face-to-face together during the facility tour on
8/15/2024. Both stated the agency has the appropriate amount of
fire extinguishers as well as ceiling sprinklers. The doors on youth
bedrooms lock from the outside but are not capable of locking
from the inside. This is to ensure youth belongings are safe and
secure. The bedroom windows are not able to be opened and that
is due to concern of youth leaving or entering outside of approved
hours and without staff knowledge. IL Supervisor and Director of
FC Services stated the windows are able to be broken in the event
of an emergency.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility (Detroit
location) on 8/15/2024. He stated staff and other youth review
what steps to take in case of a fire or other emergency. He stated
they practice fire drills every so often but was not specific with how
often and they have an identified safe location to meet in the event
of a tornado. Youth A demonstrated that he was able to open the
door from inside his bedroom even though it was locked from the
outside. Youth A was asked about the ability to evacuate out his
bedroom window in case of an emergency since the windows do
not open. He stated he is not sure if he would be able to break it in
order to evacuate but believes he could do it.
City of Detroit Inspection Supervisor was interviewed via
telephone on September 25, 2024. He stated at least one
window per bedroom must be operational, meaning the windows
need to have the ability to open. He further stated there cannot be
anything that requires special knowledge impeding exit such as
bars on the windows.
Redford Township officials were unable to be interviewed.
Three attempts were made to speak to someone and although
voicemails were exchanged on two occasions, successful contact
made was not established.
Tour Observation:
A tour of the independent living facility at 20775 Pembroke Ave.,
Detroit, MI 48219 occurred on August 15, 2024. Upon entering the
location there is an office to the left and a common area for the
youth to the right that includes a mounted flat screen TV, couches
2

and chairs. Straight ahead is a laundry area, kitchen and a
designated, locked maintenance/storage area. There are hallways
on both sides of the entrance, each with 6 bedrooms, totaling 12
bedrooms. The facility has sprinklers on the ceiling providing
coverage for the entire building including all of the bedrooms and
common area. In addition, there are wall mounted fire
extinguishers inside the kitchen, on the outside wall of the kitchen
and down each hallway. The youth bedrooms were observed.
Each youth has a spacious bedroom with windows that do not
open, however can be broken in the event of an emergency. The
bedroom doors have locks on the outside but no lock on the
inside, so youth are able to exit from the inside even if the door is
locked from the outside. I asked staff to “lock me in” and I was
easily able to exit with no issues. There are posted evacuation
plans on the wall.
A tour of the independent living facility at 26645 W. Six Mile Rd.,
Redford, MI 48240 occurred on August 15, 2024. Upon entering
the location there is an open concept that allows you to view the
far wall from the entrance. Just inside the door is a common area,
kitchen, dining seating for the youth and a larger common area
with a TV and adequate seating. Several fire alarms and
sprinklers are visible throughout the facility. In addition, there are
several fire extinguishers, including a large one inside the kitchen
area. This location has 10 youth bedrooms. Each bedroom has 2-
3 large windows that can be used in the event of an emergency.
The windows do not open, however can be broken in the event of
an emergency. The bedroom doors have locks on the outside but
no lock on the inside, so youth are able to exit from the inside
even if the door is locked from the outside. I asked staff to “lock
me in” and I was easily able to exit with no issues. Evacuation
plans on posted on the wall.
Analysis The agency is found in non-compliance. Based upon completed
interviews and observation of the independent living facilities the
bedroom windows are not able to be opened in the event of an
emergency. The windows do appear to be easily broken, however,
according to zoning requirements the windows must be
operational.
Conclusion Violation Established
3

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
